body:
In my experience most is_a?(Array/Enumerable) should be is_a?(Array) ||
is_a?(Relation), already fixed a bunch of these in our app when upgrading
to rails 3, since relation is a array/enumerable and wants to be treated
that way.


On Tue, Jul 2, 2013 at 1:09 PM, Alex Grant <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> That does seem like a separate issue. Though I don't think the scenario
> you outlined is supported -- the docs<http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveModel/Serializers/JSON.html#method-i-as_json>say that
> :include is for including associations (defined by has_many, has_one,
> etc), not arbitrary relations. This approach might work better:
>
> class Widget < ActiveRecord::Base
>   has_many :parts
>   has_many :special_parts, conditions: { is_special: true }, class_name: 'Part'
> end
>
> > Widget.first.as_json(include: :special_parts)
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/2200#issuecomment-20372174>
> .
>
